message: I run a photography site called Aminus3 (http://aminus3.com) - it looks like our images (stored on S3) are being blocked by Iranian Goverment. Unfortunately - we have a large user base of Iranian photobloggers who are not so happy about this. Any ideas on what we can do?
Anything you have already tried? (tor services etc)

have not tried anything yet - on the user side - I'm sure any proxy/VPN solution that gets the user out of the Iranian IP space would bypass the block. I guess my idea for a discussion is more about from a server perpective, what options are there to ensure users can view your site/content?
http://einmachglas.files.wordpress.com/2009/04/zensursula_seite_09.png
Post instructions on how to defeat censor-walls. Everyone should know how!
Sorry to state the obvious but you would have to host your images on ips that are not blocked. Perhaps for those users you could have a secondary store that would be active for them. Nice site btw.
The only way that I can see a site being unable to be blocked is if it was only an IP or a user / self-hosted site
Agreed
Is it specifically your site being blocked or have they done something silly like block all of S3?
true - certainly an option
could work as well
we are a photo community and some photographers post nudes... this has been the case for the last 5 years and we've not been censored
might be a good solution
maybe better to educate our users on proxies !
(previous solution also depends on how they are blocking, if it's DNS level for example that won't work)

You could make yourself a moving target... keep moving IPs etc, make it hard for them to know who to block. This might piss them off though - if you become the premier site for users wanting to bitch about their government, that might increase the risk of using your site

they are not blocking our main site - only our images (I suspect because we allow nude content) - we host our images in an S3 bucket and I figure they are blocking the bucket address (aka http://aminus3.s3.amazonaws.com/) -- one answer is to change our bucket name although that would be a huge PITA due to external links
@ZoFreX just saw your S3 question... I can't imagine they blocked all of S3 but I envision them keeping an S3 block list perhaps that they just keep adding buckets to
yeah - that is for sure !
its seems to be a sad trend gaining momentum (govt blocking web)
I'm just curious here on convore if any web devs have experienced this yet
or to get a new one for the site but leave the old address up for links
if you can have a totally custom URL for the bucket you might wanna consider that, makes it easier to move around
as for the blocking... do you need nude content?

if that's why it's getting blocked then I would consider changing the policy, or splitting the hosting so nude images go on one bucket, everything else on another... or even splitting the site, fork a new version that's less likely to get blocked
might work. it's all guesswork, really
ah I see
perhaps... is it possible to throw a 301 redirect on the old bucket address if you move?
yeah - I was thinking that though - we do have an "adult" flag so we could move those images to other bucket
just... be careful, these people don't fuck around :P
if you can work out what level you're being blocked at that might help if you do want to start actively evading
yeah - its hard to say for sure also what is fully being blocked and where
yup very true
Which was accomplished by rotating the physical location of the server, and handing out pieces of paper with the new IP address on
I have some experience with evading blocking, but that was a service on a LAN not a WAN
@ZoFreX - that's one way to approach it :)
